Security Example 1

You want to define security for a project database so that users outside the project database are prevented from accessing its archives. All users have the same set of privileges. For this level of security, complete the following steps of Setting Up Security:

    Step 2 (optional) - Specifying the location of the access control database. This step is optional because by default, an access control database is automatically assigned to a project database. And because you are defining security for the entire project database--not for individual projects, you do not need to perform this step unless you wish to change the access control database that is currently assigned to the project database or its location.

    Step 3 (optional) - Define custom privilege sets. This step is optional because you can assign individual privileges or the default privilege sets provided in Version Manager to your users. If the default privilege sets do not meet your needs, you will need to define a custom privilege set and assign it to the users when you create them.

    Step 4 - Define users. You define all the users who require access to the project database, which includes assigning privileges to users. You can assign individual privileges, the custom privilege sets you created in step 3, or any one of the default privilege sets that Version Manager provides.

    Step 7 - Enable security. Before security is active for the project database, you must set the configuration option that tells the project database to use the access control database in which you've created the users and assigned the privileges.


If you need a slightly increased level of security for the project database where the users have different roles that they perform on the archives, see security example 2.
